newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index scores record close.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index scores record close.

text.p: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index scored a record closing high on Friday, as a surge of liquidity into blue chips during afternoon trade and a buoyant tone in the red chip sector propelled prices higher.
The Hang Seng Index closed 119.68 points, or 0.84 percent, higher at 14,331.68, the highest level of the session.
Turnover was HK$14.98 billion compared with HK$14.21 billion on Thursday.
"It's index buying -- a surge of liquidity in the market," said Geoff Galbraith, institutional sales trader at NAVA SC Securities.
Among the blue chips, HSBC Holdings Plc jumped HK$3.00 to close at HK$223.00, Swire Pacific Ltd advanced HK$1.00 to HK$65.00 and Henderson Land Development Co Ltd rose HK$0.75 to HK$75.25.
"The market looks fine. It is well supported," said Richard Verin, head of equity trading at CS First Boston.
"Every time it looks like it is going to come off it doesn't. There seems to be plenty of cash around to support the market," he said.
Verin said the red chip sector continued to draw in much of the market turnover.
Shares in Shanghai Industrial Holdings Ltd gained HK$0.90 to HK$44.00 and China Resources Enterprise Ltd jumped HK$0.85 to HK$26.20. CITIC Pacific Ltd gained HK$0.50 to HK$44.60.
Shares in China-backed Chu Kong Shipping Development made their market debut on Friday, tripling in price to close at HK$3.60 compared with an issue price of HK$1.20.

Beijing Enterprises initial public offering closed on Friday with a last minute dash by investors to get their applications in before the midday deadline. The red chip said it had received "a significant number of applications" and that it would not cash cheques for applications for 6,000 or less shares.
Galbraith said the money could be redirected back into the market.
Brokers said the market was likely to retain a firm tone next week with investors likely to buy on any dips.
Galbraith noted that the futures were at a slight premium to the cash market, indicating investor optimism.
The May Hang Seng Index future rose 83 points to close at 14,338 and the June contract ended 90 points higher at 14,390.
